Mcnabb-Mallory Rule.origin: [after McNabb v. United States , 318 U.S. 332 (1943) and Mallory v. United States , 354 U.S. 449 (1957), U.S. Supreme Court cases that established the rule]

1.1: a doctrine in criminal procedure: an arrestee must be brought before a magistrate without unnecessary delay in order for a confession made during detention to be admissible
1.note: In practice, the rule is not absolute. Under the U.S. Code, a delay of more than six hours in bringing an arrestee before a magistrate will not render a confession inadmissible if the delay was reasonable in light of distance and transportation.
